newsitem.title: CANADA: Bre-X can't explain test differences - CP.
newsitem.headline: Bre-X can't explain test differences - CP.

text.p: The head of Bre-X Minerals Ltd urged shareholders on Tuesday to be patient but found it hard to explain different test results from its Indonesian gold deposit, the Canadian Press news agency said.
"To the people that have been able to maintain their position, I say have patience," Bre-X Chief Executive David Walsh said in an interview from Calgary with Canadian Press.
"And for the people who were forced to sell, I feel for them. It's a tragedy but it's not of Bre-X's making."

Bre-X has been under heavy fire since last week when its partner in Indonesia, Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc, said its early drilling samples on the Busang gold property turned up "insignificant" amounts of gold. This led to a sharp drop in Bre-X's stock and shook the Canadian stock market.

Bre-X, which had previously stated the property could hold up to 71 million ounces of gold, publicly said on Tuesday it needed more time to study a report from engineering firm Kilborn SNC-Lavalin related to a check assay programme at Busang.
It also has hired the Canadian consulting firm Strathcona Mineral Services Ltd to audit drilling, sampling and assaying of the Busang project.

CP reported that Walsh said he did not believe anyone could have inflated test results by adding gold to the thousands of samples Bre-X pulled from underneath the Indonesian jungle: "There's nothing impossible, but I'd say impossible."
He voiced confidence in the Bre-X exploration team in Indonesia and said discrepancies might come down to different testing techniques used by Bre-X and potential partner Freeport-McMoRan.
"That is the only thing that comes to my mind, some kind of difference in assaying procedure," he was quoted as saying. "That's the only possible explanation that I personally can think of.
"I don't mean to be trite about this (but) we here at Bre- X... have one word for the discrepancies, and the word is mind- boggling."
Walsh said the answer should come in about a month from the Strathcona audit, CP reported. Walsh said he wanted to correlate that information with that of Kilborn's.

Asked if he could understand why some people were questioning the deposit, Walsh said: "I don't know why they have the doubts that they have. Since we started this in 1993, we have consistently in one form or another been berated."
He added: "It's human nature, people who want to be negative are going to be negative."
